Emulating Full Client Participation: A Long-Term Client Selection Strategy for Federated Learning

Qingming Li, Juzheng Miao, Puning Zhao, Li Zhou, Shouling Ji, Bowen Zhou, Furui Liu This work was supported by National Key R&D Program of China (2023ZD0121400, 2023ZD0121401). Abstract

Client selection significantly affects the system convergence efficiency and is a crucial problem in federated learning. Existing methods often select clients by evaluating each round individually and overlook the necessity for long-term optimization, resulting in suboptimal performance and potential fairness issues. In this study, we propose a novel client selection strategy designed to emulate the performance achieved with full client participation. In a single round, we select clients by minimizing the gradient-space estimation error between the client subset and the full client set. In multi-round selection, we introduce a novel individual fairness constraint, which ensures that clients with similar data distributions have similar frequencies of being selected. This constraint guides the client selection process from a long-term perspective. We employ Lyapunov optimization and submodular functions to efficiently identify the optimal subset of clients, and provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence ability. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed strategy significantly improves both accuracy and fairness compared to previous methods while also exhibiting efficiency by incurring minimal time overhead.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Client Selection, Individual Fairness, Coreset Selection, Lyapunov Optimization

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) facilitates collaborative model training without the necessity of sharing local data [1, 2], and is widely used in various domains [3, 4, 5]. In FL, model parameters or gradient updates are frequently exchanged between the central server and participating clients, leading to substantial communication overhead. To address the challenge posed by the limited bandwidth, a common approach is to select a subset of clients for local training, which reduces the communication costs compared with involving all clients [6, 7]. However, in heterogeneous scenarios, different selection strategies lead to distinct optimization trajectories, and an improper client selection strategy can cause the optimization trajectory to deviate seriously from the optimal one, significantly hindering the model performance. Therefore, a critical challenge is to develop an effective client selection strategy that reduces the communication overhead while ensuring model convergence.

In most cases, the global models generated by full client participation are considered the gold standard or benchmark. This is because they represent models trained on the entire dataset available across all clients, offering a comprehensive reference point for evaluating model performance. Building upon this understanding, we propose an intuitive strategy where clients are selected in a manner that ensures the optimization trajectory closely resembles that achieved with full client participation over the long term. We refer to this strategy as the long-term client selection strategy. This strategy yields two key advantages. First, by emulating the optimization trajectory of full client participation, it aims to achieve comparable performance. Moreover, it reduces communication overhead by involving only a subset of clients in the process.

Our Goal. In this work, we investigate the three questions: 1) what principles should be followed to implement this strategy; 2) how to mathematically formulate this strategy and provide a fast solution; and 3) is this strategy more effective than existing methods? To answer the first question, we propose two crucial principles to be followed.

Principle I: In each round, the data distribution generated by the selected subset of clients should closely resemble the data distribution of the full client participation. For example, in Fig. 1 (a), clients collaboratively train an image classification model, where each client has images of only one kind of animal, and three clusters exist in their data distributions. Due to limited bandwidth, the server is required only to select three clients in each round. In this case, as shown in Fig. 1 (b), the ideal strategy is to select one client from each cluster instead of three clients from the same cluster. This ensures that the data distribution resulting from the subset of selected clients serves as a reliable estimation of that from the full set of clients. However, in real-world applications, the clustering pattern in data distributions may be unknown or non-existent. Therefore, the key challenge here is to determine the subset of clients that best approximates the full client set without imposing extensive assumptions on their data distributions.

However, if only Principle I is followed and client selection is performed by evaluating each round individually, there is a risk that the same subset of clients may be consistently selected across multiple rounds, while others may have minimal opportunities for selection. This phenomenon is indeed observed in our experimental results. In such cases, the system may accurately predict outcomes for frequently selected clients but makes inaccurate or biased predictions for those rarely selected, resulting in degradation of the global model’s performance and ineffective convergence. Furthermore, these seldom-selected clients may perceive unfair treatment and lose motivation to participate, ultimately endangering the sustainability of the federated system.

To mitigate this problem, we propose Principle II, which guides client selection across multiple rounds from a long-term perspective. Principle II: In multi-round selection, clients with similar data distributions should have similar frequencies of being selected. For example, as illustrated in Fig. 1, clients 1, 2, and 3 should share similar selection frequencies, as should clients 4 and 5, while the frequencies for clients 1 and 4 may differ. This principle aligns with the concept of individual fairness (IF) in central machine learning [8], which posits that similar instances or individuals in a dataset should yield similar predictions or outcomes. In our work, we refer to this principle as the individual fairness constraint. Here, the key challenge is to quantify the similarity between clients in terms of data distribution and selection frequency, respectively, and further formulate individual fairness mathematically.

This proposed individual fairness offers two key benefits. First, as illustrated in Fig. 1 (c), it promotes the diversity of selected clients across multiple rounds and reduces model prediction bias. Furthermore, existing fair federated learning approaches often utilize a uniform sampling constraint [9, 10, 11] to ensure similar selection probabilities for all clients. However, this uniform approach may compromise selection performance, as it disregards the heterogeneous data distribution among clients. In contrast, our proposed fairness constraint specifically targets clients with similar data distributions. Thus, it allows for varying selection frequencies among clients with heterogeneous data distributions, such as clients 1 and 4 in Fig. 1. This flexibility enables the individual constraint to accommodate the data heterogeneity without compromising selection performance in single rounds.

Limitation of Prior Works. To address the client selection problem, a common approach is the random selection strategy [1]. Recent works have proposed various improvements, including contribution-based [12, 1, 13, 14, 15], loss-based [16, 17, 18], and cluster-based methods [19, 20]. However, these methods typically evaluate each round individually and fail to select clients from a long-term perspective, potentially leading to model biases and fairness issues. Additionally, the clustering pattern in data distributions may be unknown or non-existent, making the application of cluster-based methods challenging. Furthermore, fair federated learning has discussed collaborative fairness [13, 15, 21], group fairness [22, 22] and performance fairness [23, 24], where performance fairness aligns most closely with our objectives. Existing fair federated learning approaches often utilize a uniform sampling constraint [9, 10, 11] to ensure similar selection probabilities for all clients. However, it disregards the heterogeneous data distribution among clients and requires their selection probabilities to be uniformly similar. This may hinder the identification of the optimal subset of clients that best approximates the full set of clients.

In this study, we propose a novel long-term client selection strategy in federated learning (LongFed), designed to emulate the model performance achieved with full client participation. In a single round, we perform client selection by minimizing the estimation error between a representative subset of clients and the full set of clients. In multi-round selection, we propose a novel individual fairness constraint to promote the diversity of selected clients without compromising selection performance in single rounds. Subsequently, we formulate the client selection problem as a time-averaged optimization function and simplify it using Lyapunov optimization from control theory. In addition, leveraging the submodular nature of the optimization function, we propose a fast greedy algorithm to find the optimal subset of clients in each round. The convergence of the proposed strategy is also analyzed. We conduct extensive experiments to validate the proposed LongFed strategy. First, the proposed strategy effectively guides the system to converge along a trajectory similar to that of full client participation. Second, it outperforms prior works in terms of both accuracy and fairness. Last, the proposed strategy introduces minimal time overhead compared to the random selection strategy. Our contributions are as follows.

  • •

    We propose a novel long-term client selection strategy designed to guide the system to converge along a trajectory similar to that of full client participation. This strategy does not require extensive assumptions on the data distribution.

  • •

    We identify and address an issue that has been rarely discussed in previous works, i.e., the frequency of selecting clients with similar distributions. We propose an individual fairness criterion to mathematically formulate this issue and employ Lyapunov optimization to solve it.

  • •

    We provide an extensive theoretical analysis of the convergence ability of the proposed strategy.

II Related Work

Existing literature relevant to our work can be broadly categorized into two groups: client selection methods and fairness issues in federated learning.

II-A Client Selection in Federated Learning

In vanilla federated learning systems [1], the random selection strategy is commonly employed to choose clients. Recent works have proposed various improvements, including contribution-based [12, 1, 13, 14, 15], loss-based [16, 17, 18], and cluster-based methods [19, 20].

The first type focuses on evaluating client contributions, where clients with higher contributions are assigned higher selection probabilities. One commonly used metric is the local data size, and clients with larger datasets are considered to have higher contributions [12, 1]. Another approach involves employing the Shapley value [25] from game theory, which calculates the average marginal model improvement of each client over all possible coalitions [13, 14, 15]. Clients that result in larger model performance improvements are regarded as making larger contributions and are assigned higher probabilities of selection. Additionally, some methods evaluate the similarity between the local model at each client and the aggregated global model at the server. Clients with higher similarities are considered to bring little improvement to the global model and are thus assigned lower selection probabilities in subsequent training epochs [21, 26].

The second type involves selecting clients based on their training losses. These methods consider that clients with higher training losses may struggle to effectively fit their local data. As a result, they assign higher selection probabilities or weights to these clients [16, 17]. FedCor is a representative work in loss-based approaches that employs Gaussian processes to model the loss correlations between clients and selects clients with a substantial reduction in expected global loss [18]. Furthermore, recognizing that clients may contain similar and redundant information, a diverse strategy is proposed to choose a subset of clients that can best represent the full client set [27].

The third approach involves a cluster-based strategy. Recognizing that clients may have different data distributions or have their own learning tasks, these clustering-based approaches divide the clients into several clusters. Clients within the same cluster exhibit similar data distributions, whereas those in different clusters may display significant variations in their data distributions. In aggregation, the server randomly selects a client from each cluster. In this cluster-based paradigm, FedCG leverages a graph neural network to capture gradient sharing across multiple clusters [19]. Moreover, IFCA addresses the cluster identification problem by determining the cluster membership of each client and optimizes each of the cluster models in a federated learning framework [20].

However, most of these methods select clients by evaluating each round individually, thus failing to optimize a series of client subsets from a long-term perspective. These limitations could cause potential model biases and fairness issues, ultimately resulting in lower convergence efficiency. Furthermore, if the clustering pattern among clients is known, the long-term client selection problem becomes straightforward: simply selecting one client randomly from each cluster in every communication round [20]. However, in practical scenarios, the clustering pattern is usually unknown or, in some cases, does not exist. This limitation renders cluster-based methods ineffective for solving the long-term client selection problem.

II-B Fairness in Federated Learning

There are three types of fairness in federated learning: collaborative fairness, group fairness, and performance fairness. Collaborative fairness emphasizes that clients who make larger contributions should be rewarded with correspondingly larger rewards, and the assessment of client contributions is a key challenge. Client contribution evaluation methods have been discussed in Section II-A in the context of contribution-based client selection methods.

Group fairness [28], also known as algorithmic fairness, emphasizes that model outputs should not unfairly discriminate against vulnerable or underrepresented groups, such as minorities, women, or the aged [29]. FairFed [22] serves as one of the representative works of addressing this concern. In FairFed, both global fairness metrics at the server and local fairness metrics at each client are defined. These metrics assess disparities in opportunities among different groups. FairFed then dynamically adjusts aggregation weights at each round based on the discrepancies between global and local fairness metrics, which effectively mitigates the biases towards sensitive attributes [22].

Performance fairness refers that the model should produce similar performance across all clients, where the uniformity of performance is commonly used as the metric for evaluation [30, 31]. Various approaches have emerged to achieve performance fairness. For example, in [24], fairness is defined by assigning uniform weight to each client and introduced as an additional constraint in the optimization function. Besides, [23] identifies a trade-off between model robustness and fairness, and proposes a personalized framework to inherently achieve both fairness and robustness benefits. Moreover, several works study the fairness issue by considering that the probability of being selected is similar for all clients [9, 10, 11].

However, the three types of fairness described above cannot effectively address the fairness issue outlined in Principle II. While collaborative fairness and group fairness focus on different aspects compared to our work, performance fairness aligns most closely with our objectives. In these works [9, 10, 11], the uniform sampling method ensures a similar probability of being selected for all clients. However, we argue that it is unsuitable for achieving the long-term client selection strategy. This is because the uniform sampling method disregards the heterogeneous data distribution among clients. Consequently, it may hinder the identification of the optimal subset of clients that best approximates the data distribution of full client participation.

III The Proposed Optimization Function

In this section, we begin with an introduction to the federated learning system. Next, we illustrate the client selection in a single round and across multiple rounds, followed by the proposed long-term optimization function. Last, we apply Lyapunov optimization to transform and simplify the optimization function.

III-B The Optimization Function

III-B1 Client Selection in a Single Round

In a single round, we identify the subset of clients that best approximates the data distribution of the full set of clients. Specifically, we evaluate the estimation error between the aggregated gradient obtained from the client subset 𝕊tsuperscript𝕊𝑡\mathbb{S}^{t} and the aggregated gradient obtained from the full client set ℕℕ\mathbb{N}. A small estimation error indicates that the subset of selected clients can effectively represent the data distribution of the full client set. Mathematically, we formulate it as

D​(𝕊t)=minθjt>0​‖∑i∈ℕ∇fi​(𝒘t)−∑j∈𝕊tθjt​∇fj​(𝒘t)‖22.Dsuperscript𝕊𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡0superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑖ℕ∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝒘𝑡22\displaystyle\text{D}(\mathbb{S}^{t})=\min_{\theta_{j}^{t}>0}||\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})||_{2}^{2}. (2)

Here, ∇fi​(𝒘t)∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) represents the gradient of the i𝑖i-th client, ∑i∈ℕ∇fi​(𝒘t)subscript𝑖ℕ∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) is the aggregated gradient on the full client set ℕℕ\mathbb{N}, and ∑j∈𝕊tθjt​∇fj​(𝒘t)subscript𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝒘𝑡\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t}) denotes the weighted sum of gradients on the client subset 𝕊tsuperscript𝕊𝑡\mathbb{S}^{t}. Then, selecting a subset of clients that best approximates the data distribution of the full client set is equivalent to choosing a subset that minimizes the estimation error defined in Eq. (2).

Notice that the formation in Eq. (2) is similar to the concept of data coreset introduced in [32]. The data coreset involves selecting a weighted small sample of training data to approximate the gradient of the whole training data set. It is important to highlight that data coreset is commonly employed to enhance training efficiency in centralized machine learning scenarios [33, 34], while our focus is on optimizing client selection to reduce communication bandwidth in decentralized and federated scenarios. Moreover, data coreset is typically utilized for a one-time data selection process, while client selection in federated learning is a long-term process carried out across multiple rounds. The long-term optimization nature introduces new challenges, such as fairness issues and potential model biases introduced in Section I.

III-B2 Client Selection Across Multiple Rounds

In our work, we propose a novel fairness constraint to guide the client selection process across multiple rounds. This constraint asserts that clients with similar data distributions should have similar frequencies of being selected.

To formulate the fairness constraint, we establish metrics to measure the similarity between a pair of clients in terms of their data distributions and the frequencies of being selected, respectively. First, we use Disti,j​(t)subscriptDist𝑖𝑗𝑡\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t) in Eq. (4) to measure the similarity of the data distribution and use Eq. (5) to compute its value. Second, let xi,tsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i,t} represent whether the i𝑖i-th client is selected in the t𝑡t-th round, with xi,t=1subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡1x_{i,t}=1 if i∈𝕊t𝑖superscript𝕊𝑡i\in\mathbb{S}^{t} and xi,t=0subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡0x_{i,t}=0 otherwise. We use

pi=1T​∑t=1T𝔼​(xi,t).subscript𝑝𝑖1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡\displaystyle p_{i}=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}(x_{i,t}). (6)

to evaluate the frequency of a client i𝑖i being selected throughout the total T𝑇T rounds. Note that {xi,t}subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡\{x_{i,t}\} forms a stochastic process, and the expectation operation 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} is applied in Eq. (6). Given two clients i,j∈ℕ𝑖𝑗ℕi,j\in\mathbb{N}, we use |pi−pj|subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗|p_{i}-p_{j}| to quantify the difference between their frequencies of being selected.

Building on Disti,j​(t)subscriptDist𝑖𝑗𝑡\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t) and pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}, we employ the ϵ​-​δitalic-ϵ-𝛿\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF framework utilized in [35, 36] to quantify the fairness constraint. We evaluate a client selection strategy at the end of the T𝑇T-th communication round. Specifically, given ϵ,δ≥0italic-ϵ𝛿0\epsilon,\delta\geq 0, a client selection strategy is of individual fairness if for every pair of clients i,j∈ℕ𝑖𝑗ℕi,j\in\mathbb{N} with Disti,j​(T)≤ϵsubscriptDist𝑖𝑗𝑇italic-ϵ\text{Dist}_{i,j}(T)\leq\epsilon, the difference in their frequencies of being selected, namely, pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} and pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j}, should not exceed δ𝛿\delta. The mathematical formulation of ϵ​-​δitalic-ϵ-𝛿\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF is provided in Definition 1, and the impact of parameter selection for ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and δ𝛿\delta is discussed in Section V-C.

Definition 1.

(ϵ​-​δitalic-ϵ-𝛿\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF). Consider ϵ,δ≥0italic-ϵ𝛿0\epsilon,\delta\geq 0, a client selection strategy is said to be of individual fairness if

∀i,j∈ℕ,Disti,j​(T)≤ϵ⇒|pi−pj|≤δ.formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝑗ℕsubscriptDist𝑖𝑗𝑇italic-ϵ⇒subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗𝛿\displaystyle\forall\,i,j\in\mathbb{N},\,\,\text{Dist}_{i,j}(T)\leq\epsilon\,\,\Rightarrow\,\,|p_{i}-p_{j}|\leq\delta. (7)

Note that ϵ​-​δitalic-ϵ-𝛿\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF requires examining Eq. (7) for all pairs of clients, leading to significant computational overhead and rendering subsequent optimization challenging. To address this issue, we propose to determine a reference client i⋆superscript𝑖⋆i^{\star} for each client i𝑖i, which exhibits the largest difference in the frequency of being selected among clients whose gradient distances are less than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. That is,

i⋆=argmaxDisti,j​(T)≤ϵ​|pi−pj|,∀j∈ℕ.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑖⋆subscriptargmaxsubscriptDist𝑖𝑗𝑇italic-ϵsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑗for-all𝑗ℕ\displaystyle i^{\star}=\text{argmax}_{\text{Dist}_{i,j}(T)\leq\epsilon}\,|p_{i}-p_{j}|,\;\forall\;j\in\mathbb{N}. (8)

Then, given a client i𝑖i and its reference client i⋆superscript𝑖⋆i^{\star}, a client selection strategy is certified as ϵ​-​δitalic-ϵ-𝛿\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF if

|pi−pi⋆|≤δ,∀i∈ℕ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝superscript𝑖⋆𝛿for-all𝑖ℕ\displaystyle|p_{i}-p_{i^{\star}}|\leq\delta,\quad\forall\;i\in\mathbb{N}. (9)

By introducing the reference client in Eq. (8), the evaluation of ϵ​-​δitalic-ϵ-𝛿\epsilon\text{-}\delta-IF is simplified from examining Eq. (7) for pairs of clients i,j∈ℕ𝑖𝑗ℕi,j\in\mathbb{N} to evaluating Eq. (9) for individual clients i∈ℕ𝑖ℕi\in\mathbb{N}. This reduction in the number of variables facilitates further optimization.

III-B3 The Optimization Function

Building on the estimation error in Eq. (2) and the individual fairness constraint in Eq. (9), we formulate the client selection strategy as an optimization problem. The objective is to select a series of subsets {𝕊1,⋯,𝕊T}superscript𝕊1⋯superscript𝕊𝑇\{\mathbb{S}^{1},\cdots,\mathbb{S}^{T}\} with |𝕊t|=Ksuperscript𝕊𝑡𝐾|\mathbb{S}^{t}|=K that minimize the expected estimation error over all T𝑇T rounds while adhering to the individual fairness constraint. That is,

(P1) min{𝕊1,⋯,𝕊T}​limT→+∞1T​∑t=1T𝔼​[DUB​(𝕊t)],subscriptsuperscript𝕊1⋯superscript𝕊𝑇subscript→𝑇1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼delimited-[]DUBsuperscript𝕊𝑡\displaystyle\min_{\{\mathbb{S}^{1},\cdots,\mathbb{S}^{T}\}}\;\lim_{T\to+\infty}\frac{1}{T}\,\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}\left[\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t})\right], (10)
s.t.Eq. (9).s.t.Eq. (9)\displaystyle\qquad\textrm{s.t.}\quad\quad\text{Eq. \eqref{equ:client_star_IF}}.

However, directly solving the optimization function in Eq. (10) is infeasible. The optimization objective and constraints, particularly pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} in Eq. (9), are presented in a time-averaged form. That is, these values are determined by averaging over all T𝑇T rounds, which can only be accomplished at the end of training. In contrast, federated learning requires clients to be selected online in each round. This misalignment poses a practical implementation challenge. In our work, the solution to address this misalignment is proposed in Section III-C.

III-C Problem Transformation Under Lyapunov Optimization

To solve P1 in Eq. (10), we leverage Lyapunov optimization, a technique from control theory used to analyze the stability of dynamic systems [37, 9]. The main idea behind Lyapunov optimization is to break down the long-term time-averaged constraints in the optimization problem into constraints that can be adhered to in each communication round. This allows us to optimize the objective function directly in each round without violating the constraints specific to that round. Furthermore, by ensuring that these constraints are adhered to in each round, we can automatically achieve compliance with the long-term time-averaged constraints at the end of the T𝑇T round. By leveraging Lyapunov optimization, the problem stated as P1 in Eq. (10) is ultimately converted into the problem P3 in Eq. (23), which can be efficiently solved online in each communication round. Details of problem transformation are described below.

Before employing Lyapunov optimization, we remove the absolute value sign from the constraint in Eq. (9) and rephrase it as two equivalent constraints,

1T​∑t=1T𝔼​(xi,t−xi⋆,t)−δ≤0,∀i∈ℕ,formulae-sequence1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥superscript𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿0for-all𝑖ℕ\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}(x_{i,t}-x_{i^{\star},t})-\delta\leq 0,\;\forall\,i\in\mathbb{N}, (11)
1T​∑t=1T𝔼​(−xi,t+xi⋆,t)−δ≤0,∀i∈ℕ.formulae-sequence1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥superscript𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿0for-all𝑖ℕ\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}(-x_{i,t}+x_{i^{\star},t})-\delta\leq 0,\;\forall\,i\in\mathbb{N}. (12)

Lyapunov optimization typically involves three steps [37]. First, a virtual queue is defined for each time-averaged constraint. This step converts the time-averaged constraints into stability constraints for virtual queues. Second, a Lyapunov function is defined based on virtual queues, and the Lyapunov drift is introduced. This step breaks down the time-averaged constraints into requirements for Lyapunov drift in each communication round. Finally, the Lyapunov drift is integrated into the optimization objective, allowing us to minimize both the Lyapunov drift and the optimization objective simultaneously. In the following, we illustrate how to transform problem P1 using these three steps.

First, we define two virtual queues, namely Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t) for the constraint in Eq. (11) and Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t) for the constraint in Eq. (12), for all clients i∈ℕ𝑖ℕi\in\mathbb{N}. Specifically, these queues are initialized as Zi​(0)=0subscript𝑍𝑖00Z_{i}(0)=0 and Qi​(0)=0subscript𝑄𝑖00Q_{i}(0)=0, and updated according to the following rule

Zi​(t+1)=max⁡{Zi​(t)+xi,t−xi⋆,t−δ,0},subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥superscript𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿0\displaystyle Z_{i}(t+1)=\max\left\{Z_{i}(t)+x_{i,t}-x_{i^{\star},t}-\delta,0\right\}, (13)
Qi​(t+1)=max⁡{Qi​(t)−xi,t+xi⋆,t−δ,0}.subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥superscript𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿0\displaystyle Q_{i}(t+1)=\max\left\{Q_{i}(t)-x_{i,t}+x_{i^{\star},t}-\delta,0\right\}.

By the introduction of Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t) and Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t), we have Theorem 2, which converts the long-term constraints on xi,tsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i,t} in Eq. (11) and (12) into the stability constraints for Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t) and Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t). The proof of Theorem 2 is provided in the supplementary file.

Theorem 2.

The constraints in Eq. (11) and (12) hold if Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t) and Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t) remain stable, that is,

limT→+∞𝔼​[Zi​(T)]T=0,and​limT→+∞𝔼​[Qi​(T)]T=0.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑇𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑍𝑖𝑇𝑇0andsubscript→𝑇𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑄𝑖𝑇𝑇0\displaystyle\lim_{T\to+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{E}[Z_{i}(T)]}{T}=0,\;\text{and}\;\lim_{T\to+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{E}[Q_{i}(T)]}{T}=0. (14)

To make Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t) and Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t) remain stable, an intuitive approach is to bound the increase of these queues in each round so that they could not grow to infinity. Based on this intuition, in our work, we define a global queue Θ​(t)Θ𝑡\Theta(t), which stores the state of Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t) and Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t) for all clients. That is,

Θ​(t)≜[Z1​(t),⋯,Zn​(t),Q1​(t),⋯,Qn​(t)].≜Θ𝑡subscript𝑍1𝑡⋯subscript𝑍𝑛𝑡subscript𝑄1𝑡⋯subscript𝑄𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\Theta(t)\triangleq\left[Z_{1}(t),\cdots,Z_{n}(t),Q_{1}(t),\cdots,Q_{n}(t)\right]. (15)

Second, following Lyapunov optimization, we define the Lyapunov function [37] as

L​(Θ​(t))≜12​∑i=1N[Zi2​(t)+Qi2​(t)],≜𝐿Θ𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑖2𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑖2𝑡\displaystyle L\left(\Theta(t)\right)\triangleq\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[Z_{i}^{2}(t)+Q_{i}^{2}(t)\right], (16)

which represents the sum of the squares of all elements in Θ​(t)Θ𝑡\Theta(t). Then, the increase of Θ​(t)Θ𝑡\Theta(t) from the communication round t𝑡t to (t+1)𝑡1(t+1) is formulated as

Δ​(Θ​(t))≜𝔼​[L​(Θ​(t+1))−L​(Θ​(t))|Θ​(t)],≜ΔΘ𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝐿Θ𝑡1conditional𝐿Θ𝑡Θ𝑡\displaystyle\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right)\triangleq\mathbb{E}\left[L\left(\Theta(t+1)\right)-L\left(\Theta(t)\right)|\Theta(t)\right], (17)

which is called Lyapunov drift [37]. If the drift Δ​(Θ​(t))ΔΘ𝑡\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) remains sufficiently small in each round, the constraints in Eq. (11) and Eq. (12) will be satisfied after T𝑇T rounds. That is, introducing Δ​(Θ​(t))ΔΘ𝑡\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) allows us to break down the time-averaged constraints in Eq. (11) and Eq. (12) into the specific requirements for Δ​(Θ​(t))ΔΘ𝑡\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) in each communication round.

At last, to ensure that Δ​(Θ​(t))ΔΘ𝑡\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) remains sufficiently small, a straightforward method to combine the optimization objection with the drift Δ​(Θ​(t))ΔΘ𝑡\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right), and minimize both simultaneously. Mathematically, in our work, the optimization problem in Eq. (10) is transformed into

(P2)​min𝕊t(1−V)⋅Δ​(Θ​(t))+V⋅DUB​(𝕊t)(P2)subscriptsuperscript𝕊𝑡⋅1𝑉ΔΘ𝑡⋅𝑉DUBsuperscript𝕊𝑡\displaystyle\text{(P2)}\;\min_{\mathbb{S}^{t}}\quad(1-V)\cdot\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right)+V\cdot\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) (18)

with |𝕊t|=Ksuperscript𝕊𝑡𝐾|\mathbb{S}^{t}|=K as a constraint, where V𝑉V is a predefined trade-off factor. Note that the expectation notation 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} is dropped since we are only concerned with a single communication round.

However, solving P2 in Eq. (18) still presents two challenges. First, determining i⋆superscript𝑖⋆i^{\star} requires the information about pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}, which is not available until the end of training. To address the issue, we calculate the frequency of a client i𝑖i being selected up to the t𝑡t-th round, denoted as pi​(t)=1t​∑k=1txi,tsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡p_{i}(t)=\frac{1}{t}\sum_{k=1}^{t}x_{i,t}. Then, we determine the reference client in the t𝑡t-th round by

it⋆=argmaxDisti,j​(t)≤ϵ​|pi​(t)−pj​(t)|,∀j∈ℕ.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑖⋆𝑡subscriptargmaxsubscriptDist𝑖𝑗𝑡italic-ϵsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡subscript𝑝𝑗𝑡for-all𝑗ℕ\displaystyle i^{\star}_{t}=\text{argmax}_{\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t)\leq\epsilon}|p_{i}(t)-p_{j}(t)|,\;\forall\,j\in\mathbb{N}. (19)

In our experiment, we replace the reference client i⋆superscript𝑖⋆i^{\star} in Eq. (8) with it⋆subscriptsuperscript𝑖⋆𝑡i^{\star}_{t} in Eq. (19), thus it can be determined using information available up to the t𝑡t-th round.

Additionally, because the computation of Δ​(Θ​(t))ΔΘ𝑡\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) requires information about L​(Θ​(t+1))𝐿Θ𝑡1L\left(\Theta(t+1)\right), which is not available in the current round t𝑡t. To overcome this issue, we derive an upper bound for Δ​(Θ​(t))ΔΘ𝑡\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) using Theorem 3 and minimize the upper bound instead. The proof is provided in the supplementary file.

Theorem 3.

Define

mi,t=xi,t−xit⋆,t−δ,and​ni,t=−xi,t+xit⋆,t−δ,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑖⋆𝑡𝑡𝛿andsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑖⋆𝑡𝑡𝛿\displaystyle m_{i,t}=x_{i,t}-x_{i^{\star}_{t},t}-\delta,\;\text{and}\;n_{i,t}=-x_{i,t}+x_{i^{\star}_{t},t}-\delta, (20)

then Δ​(Θ​(t))ΔΘ𝑡\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right) is bounded by

Δ​(Θ​(t))≤B+∑i=1N[Zi​(t)​mi,t+Qi​(t)​ni,t],ΔΘ𝑡𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁delimited-[]subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡subscript𝑚𝑖𝑡subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡subscript𝑛𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\Delta\left(\Theta(t)\right)\leq B+\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[Z_{i}(t)m_{i,t}+Q_{i}(t)n_{i,t}\right], (21)

where B𝐵B is a constant.

Based on Theorem 3, the problem P2 in Eq. (18) is transformed into

min𝕊t⁡(1−V)​∑i=1N[Zi​(t)​mi,t+Qi​(t)​ni,t]+V⋅DUB​(𝕊t).subscriptsuperscript𝕊𝑡1𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁delimited-[]subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡subscript𝑚𝑖𝑡subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡subscript𝑛𝑖𝑡⋅𝑉DUBsuperscript𝕊𝑡\displaystyle\min_{\mathbb{S}^{t}}\;(1-V)\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[Z_{i}(t)m_{i,t}+Q_{i}(t)n_{i,t}\right]+V\cdot\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t}). (22)

Substituting DUB​(𝕊t)DUBsuperscript𝕊𝑡\text{DUB}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) by Eq. (3) and moving the sum sign outside of the minimum sign, the problem in Eq. (22) is equivalent to

min𝕊tG(𝕊t)=∑i=1Nminj∈𝕊t{(1−V)[Zi(t)mi,t+Qi(t)ni,t]\displaystyle\min_{\mathbb{S}^{t}}\;G(\mathbb{S}^{t})=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\min_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\Big{\{}(1-V)\big{[}Z_{i}(t)m_{i,t}+Q_{i}(t)n_{i,t}\big{]} (23)
(P3)+V⋅∥∇fi(𝒘t)−∇fj(𝒘t)∥},\displaystyle\text{(P3)}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad+V\cdot\big{\|}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}\Big{\}},

where Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t) and Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t) are defined in Eq. (13), mi,tsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡m_{i,t} and ni,tsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑡n_{i,t} are defined in Eq. (20), and V𝑉V is a hyperparameter that balances the optimization function and the fairness constraint. With an appropriate V𝑉V, the solution in Eq. (23) can infinitely approximate the optimal solution in Eq. (18) [38]. In the following, we select clients by minimizing G​(𝕊t)𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) in Eq. (23) in each round.

IV The Proposed LongFed

IV-A The Client Selection Strategy

The optimization problem in Eq. (23) is NP-hard as it involves calculating the value of G​(𝕊t)𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) for N!K!​(N−K)!𝑁𝐾𝑁𝐾\frac{N!}{K!(N-K)!} subsets, where !! denotes the factorial function [39]. To address this issue, we exploit the submodular nature of G​(𝕊t)𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡G(\mathbb{S}^{t}).

Specifically, a set function g:2ℕ→ℝ:𝑔→superscript2ℕℝg:2^{\mathbb{N}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is submodular if for every A⊆B⊆ℕ𝐴𝐵ℕA\subseteq B\subseteq\mathbb{N} and i∈ℕ\B𝑖\ℕ𝐵i\in\mathbb{N}\backslash B it holds that g​(A∪{i})−g​(A)>g​(B∪{i})−g​(B)𝑔𝐴𝑖𝑔𝐴𝑔𝐵𝑖𝑔𝐵g(A\cup\{i\})-g(A)>g(B\cup\{i\})-g(B). One typical example of a submodular function is the facility location function [40]. Suppose we aim to select locations from a set of positions ℕ={1,…,N}ℕ1…𝑁\mathbb{N}=\{1,\ldots,N\} to open facilities and to serve a collection of K𝐾K users. If a facility is located at position j𝑗j, the service it provides to user i𝑖i is quantified by Mi,jsubscript𝑀𝑖𝑗M_{i,j}. Each user is assumed to select the facility with the highest service, and the total service provided to all users is modeled by the set function

f​(𝕊)=∑i=1mmaxj∈𝕊⁡Mi,j,𝑓𝕊superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑗𝕊subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗\displaystyle f(\mathbb{S})=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\max_{j\in\mathbb{S}}M_{i,j}, (24)

where f​(∅)=0𝑓0f(\emptyset)=0. If Mi,j≥0subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗0M_{i,j}\geq 0 for all i,j𝑖𝑗i,j, then f​(𝕊)𝑓𝕊f(\mathbb{S}) is a monotone submodular function. By introducing an auxiliary element e𝑒e, the set function G​(𝕊t)𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) in Eq. (23) is transformed into

G¯​(𝕊t)=G​({e})−G​(𝕊t∪{e}),¯𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡𝐺𝑒𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡𝑒\displaystyle\overline{G}(\mathbb{S}^{t})=G(\{e\})-G(\mathbb{S}^{t}\cup\{e\}), (25)

which is a facility location function and has a submodular nature. G¯​(𝕊t)¯𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡\overline{G}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) measures the decrease in the value of G​(𝕊t)𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) associated with the set 𝕊tsuperscript𝕊𝑡\mathbb{S}^{t} compared to that associated with just the auxiliary element e𝑒e. Without loss of generality, we set the auxiliary element as e=1𝑒1e=1. Consequently, minimizing G​(𝕊t)𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡G(\mathbb{S}^{t}) in Eq. (23) is equivalent to maximizing G¯​(𝕊t)¯𝐺superscript𝕊𝑡\overline{G}(\mathbb{S}^{t}) in Eq. (25).

Prior studies show that the greedy algorithm is an effective solution for finding the maximum value of a submodular function [41, 39]. Following this greedy algorithm, we propose a strategy to select clients in the t𝑡t-th round, as outlined in Algorithm 1. The proposed strategy starts with an empty set 𝕊0t=∅superscriptsubscript𝕊0𝑡\mathbb{S}_{0}^{t}=\emptyset, and initializes a candidate set as ℙ0=ℕsubscriptℙ0ℕ\mathbb{P}_{0}=\mathbb{N} (Line 3). In an iteration k∈[0,K−1]𝑘0𝐾1k\in[0,K-1], we first determine the reference client it⋆subscriptsuperscript𝑖⋆𝑡i^{\star}_{t} for client i∈ℙk𝑖subscriptℙ𝑘i\in\mathbb{P}_{k}, and compute mi,tsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡m_{i,t} and ni,tsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑡n_{i,t} with xi,t=1subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡1x_{i,t}=1 if i∈𝕊kt𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝕊𝑡𝑘i\in\mathbb{S}^{t}_{k}, and similarly for xit⋆,tsubscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑖⋆𝑡𝑡x_{i^{\star}_{t},t} (Line 5-6). Next, we calculate G¯​(𝕊kt∪{i})¯𝐺superscriptsubscript𝕊𝑘𝑡𝑖\overline{G}(\mathbb{S}_{k}^{t}\cup\{i\}) for all clients i∈ℙk𝑖subscriptℙ𝑘i\in\mathbb{P}_{k}, and identify the client imaxsubscript𝑖maxi_{\text{max}} with the maximum value (Line 7-8). Subsequently, the client imaxsubscript𝑖maxi_{\text{max}} is removed from ℙksubscriptℙ𝑘\mathbb{P}_{k} and added to the subset 𝕊ktsuperscriptsubscript𝕊𝑘𝑡\mathbb{S}_{k}^{t} (Line 9). This iteration continues until K𝐾K clients are selected. The complexity of the algorithm is O​(K​N)𝑂𝐾𝑁O(KN).

Based on the client selection strategy in Algorithm 1, we further present the proposed federated training algorithm, as outlined in Algorithm 2. First, the server initializes the queues Zi​(0)subscript𝑍𝑖0Z_{i}(0) and Qi​(0)subscript𝑄𝑖0Q_{i}(0), along with the model parameter 𝒘0superscript𝒘0\bm{w}^{0} (Line 3). Subsequently, the server selects the subset of clients 𝕊tsuperscript𝕊𝑡\mathbb{S}^{t} (Line 5-9). If the communication round t=0𝑡0t=0, all clients are selected; otherwise, the server selects K𝐾K clients according to Algorithm 1. The server then sends the model parameter 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{t} to the selected clients, and these clients perform local training and send the gradients back to the server (Line 10-11). The server updates Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t) and Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t) according to Eq. (13), and aggregates these results to obtain the model parameter 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{t+1} according to Eq. (1). The iteration is repeated until completing the T𝑇T rounds.

IV-B Convergence Analysis

We provide a theoretical analysis to demonstrate the convergence ability of the proposed client selection strategy. The analysis uses FedAvg as the aggregation method, and it can be extended to other federated optimization methods as well. To implement the theoretical analysis, we establish six assumptions regarding the local models and data distribution heterogeneity among clients.

First, based on the effective greedy selection strategy in Algorithm 1, we assume that the estimation error between the client subset and the full client set (Eq. (2)) is small and can be quantified by a variable ρ𝜌\rho, as stated in Assumption 1. This assumption has also been studied in the context of data coreset selection [32] and client selection methods [27]. Note that ρ𝜌\rho is used as a measure to characterize the quality of the estimation, and the analysis holds for any ρ<∞𝜌\rho<\infty.

Assumption 1. At each communication round t𝑡t, we assume that the gradient aggregated from the selected subset of clients can provide a good approximation of the gradient aggregated from the full set, i.e.,

‖∑i∈ℕ∇fi​(𝒘t)−∑j∈𝕊tθjt​∇fj​(𝒘t)‖≤ρ.normsubscript𝑖ℕ∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝒘𝑡𝜌\displaystyle\left\|\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\right\|\leq\rho. (26)

Next, we outline the assumptions regarding local models f1,⋯,fNsubscript𝑓1⋯subscript𝑓𝑁f_{1},\cdots,f_{N} and their gradients ∇f1​(𝒘t),⋯,∇fN​(𝒘t)∇subscript𝑓1superscript𝒘𝑡⋯∇subscript𝑓𝑁superscript𝒘𝑡\nabla f_{1}(\bm{w}^{t}),\cdots,\nabla f_{N}(\bm{w}^{t}), as stated in Assumption 2-5. These assumptions are standard and widely used in the federated optimization literature [42, 43, 18, 27].

Assumption 2. f1,⋯,fNsubscript𝑓1⋯subscript𝑓𝑁f_{1},\cdots,f_{N} are all L𝐿L-smooth. Formally, for all 𝒗𝒗\bm{v} and 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, we have

fk​(𝒗)≤fk​(𝒘)+(𝒗−𝒘)T​∇fk​(𝒘)+L2​‖𝒗−𝒘‖22.subscript𝑓𝑘𝒗subscript𝑓𝑘𝒘superscript𝒗𝒘𝑇∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝒘𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒗𝒘22\displaystyle f_{k}(\bm{v})\leq f_{k}(\bm{w})+(\bm{v}-\bm{w})^{T}\nabla f_{k}(\bm{w})+\frac{L}{2}\|\bm{v}-\bm{w}\|_{2}^{2}. (27)

Assumption 3. f1,⋯,fNsubscript𝑓1⋯subscript𝑓𝑁f_{1},\cdots,f_{N} are all μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex. Formally, for all 𝒗𝒗\bm{v} and 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, it holds

fk​(𝒗)≥fk​(𝒘)+(𝒗−𝒘)T​∇fk​(𝒘)+μ2​‖𝒗−𝒘‖22.subscript𝑓𝑘𝒗subscript𝑓𝑘𝒘superscript𝒗𝒘𝑇∇subscript𝑓𝑘𝒘𝜇2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒗𝒘22\displaystyle f_{k}(\bm{v})\geq f_{k}(\bm{w})+(\bm{v}-\bm{w})^{T}\nabla f_{k}(\bm{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\bm{v}-\bm{w}\|_{2}^{2}. (28)

Assumption 4. The variance of gradients for fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is bounded for i∈ℕ𝑖ℕi\in\mathbb{N}. Formally, letting αitsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖𝑡\alpha_{i}^{t} be a data sample randomly chosen from the local dataset of the client i𝑖i, we have

𝔼​[‖∇fi​(𝒘it,αit)−∇fi​(𝒘it)‖]≤B2.𝔼delimited-[]norm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡subscript𝐵2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t},\alpha_{i}^{t})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t})\|\right]\leq B_{2}. (29)

Assumption 5. The expected squared norm of gradients is uniformly bounded, that is,

𝔼​[‖∇fi​(𝒘it,ξit)‖]≤B3.𝔼delimited-[]norm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡subscript𝐵3\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}_{i}^{t},\xi_{i}^{t})\|\right]\leq B_{3}. (30)

Furthermore, we introduce the term ΓΓ\Gamma in Assumption 6 to quantify the data heterogeneity among clients. If the data distribution among clients is independently and identically distributed, then ΓΓ\Gamma approaches zero as the number of clients grows. Conversely, if the data distribution is heterogeneous, the magnitude of ΓΓ\Gamma reflects the degree of heterogeneity.

Assumption 6. Let f⋆superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star} and fi⋆superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖⋆f_{i}^{\star} be the minimum values of f𝑓f and fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, respectively. We consider the degree of data heterogeneity to be bounded, that is,

Γ=‖f⋆−∑i=1Nθi​fi⋆‖≤B4.Γnormsuperscript𝑓⋆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝜃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖⋆subscript𝐵4\displaystyle\Gamma=\|f^{\star}-\sum_{i=1}^{N}\theta_{i}f_{i}^{\star}\|\leq B_{4}. (31)

Based on these assumptions, the proposed client selection strategy is demonstrated to converge to the global optimal parameter 𝒘⋆superscript𝒘⋆\bm{w}^{\star} at a rate of 𝒪​(1/t)𝒪1𝑡\mathcal{O}(1/t) for heterogeneous data settings, as stated in Theorem 4. The proof is provided in the supplementary file. The convergence rate 𝒪​(1/t)𝒪1𝑡\mathcal{O}(1/t) is the same as existing client selection methods [27, 18, 43].

Theorem 4.

Under Assumptions 1-6, we have

𝔼​‖𝒘⋆−𝒘t‖22≤𝒪​(1/t)+𝒪​(ρ).𝔼superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒘⋆superscript𝒘𝑡22𝒪1𝑡𝒪𝜌\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\bm{w}^{\star}-\bm{w}^{t}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}(1/t)+\mathcal{O}(\rho). (32)

The term ρ𝜌\rho encodes the estimation error in Eq. (2). When more clients are selected in a communication round, the subset of selected clients can better approximate the data distribution of the full client set, then the term ρ𝜌\rho is smaller. Particularly, ρ𝜌\rho becomes zero when all clients are selected in each round, i.e., K=N𝐾𝑁K=N. We also analyze the impact of varying K𝐾K empirically and propose an adaptive client selection method [44]. However, to reduce communication overhead, the number of selected clients is usually less than the total number of available clients, i.e., K<N𝐾𝑁K<N. In this case, ρ𝜌\rho remains a non-vanishing term. In experiments, we observe that the proposed client selection strategy guides the system to converge along a trajectory similar to that of full client participation, but there exists a non-diminishing solution bias dependent on ρ𝜌\rho. This observation is consistent with our theoretical analysis.

V Experiment

V-A Experimental Settings

We consider the cross-device federated learning scenario where a large number of clients exist, each with limited computational power. In our experiments, we fix the number of clients at N=100𝑁100N=100 and employ FedAvg [1] as the aggregation method. The proposed client selection strategy is evaluated on two datasets, FMNIST [45] and CIFAR-10 [46]. Following the approach in [18], we opt for basic and small-scale models to accommodate the clients’ restricted computational resources. Specifically, for the FMNIST dataset, we utilize a multilayer perception (MLP) with two hidden layers as the global model. For CIFAR-10, our global model adopts a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture consisting of three convolutional layers, with the outputs of these layers fed into an MLP layer. Further details on training and hyperparameter settings can be found in the supplementary file.

We explore four data partitioning methods, including an independently and identically distributed (IID) approach and three heterogeneous approaches. In the IID approach, we randomly partition the dataset into N𝑁N parts, with each client assigned one part. We select K=5𝐾5K=5 clients in each round. Three heterogeneous data partitioning approaches are as follows.

(i) 1 Shard Per Client (1SPC). Following the setting in [1], we divide the dataset into N𝑁N shards, ensuring that data within a shard shares the same label. We randomly assign a shard to each client so that a client has data with only one label. This is the most heterogeneous case. In this case, we select K=10𝐾10K=10 clients in each round.

(ii) 2 Shards Per Client (2SPC). Similar to the 1SPC setting, the dataset is partitioned into 2​N2𝑁2N shards, where data within each shard shares the same label. Clients are randomly assigned two shards, where most clients have data with two labels (two shards with different labels), while a few clients have data with only one label (two shards with the same label). In this case, we set K=5𝐾5K=5 in each round.

(iii) Dirichlet Distribution (Dir). We partition the dataset based on a Dirichlet distribution parameterized by a concentration variable α𝛼\alpha, where a smaller value of α𝛼\alpha indicates higher heterogeneity. In our work, we set α=0.8𝛼0.8\alpha=0.8. Under this setting, clients have data with all labels, but the data size of each label varies among clients. We determine the data size of each label for each client following the analysis in [47, 18]. In this case, we choose K=5𝐾5K=5 clients in each round.

Note that the 1SPC and 2SPC scenarios address label shift heterogeneity, while the Dir scenario accounts for heterogeneity in both labels and dataset size. Furthermore, apart from the assumption of a fixed number of clients (K𝐾K) to be selected, we also explore the impact of varying K𝐾K and propose an adaptive method to determine its value. Details of the adaptive method can be found in [44].

We conduct the experiments five times using different randomized initial conditions and present the average results. In our experiments, we set δ=0.1𝛿0.1\delta=0.1 , ϵ=0.3italic-ϵ0.3\epsilon=0.3, and V=0.9𝑉0.9V=0.9 for FMNIST, and δ=0.05𝛿0.05\delta=0.05, ϵ=0.05italic-ϵ0.05\epsilon=0.05, V=0.7𝑉0.7V=0.7 for CIFAR-10. We compare the proposed LongFed with three baseline methods: (1) the random selection strategy (Random) [1]; (2) active client selection strategy (AFL), where clients with higher training losses have higher probabilities of being selected [16]; (3) power-of-choice strategy (Powerd), where clients are selected based on the power of d𝑑d choices load balancing strategy [17]. These methods are commonly used as baselines in [18, 27]. Additionally, we compare our method with the full client participation method (Full) with K=100𝐾100K=100.

V-B Experimental Results

V-B1 Convergence Analysis

The experimental results under the IID scenario are presented in Fig. 2, and the results under three heterogeneous data partitioning methods are presented in Fig. 3. In Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, the x𝑥x axis represents the communication round, and the y𝑦y axis displays the test accuracy of the global model. For a clearer comparison, we apply the moving average rule [48] with a sliding window size of 10 to smooth the results.

Fig. 2 reveals that in the IID scenario, these methods achieve similar performance. For three heterogeneous scenarios on the FMNIST dataset, as shown in Fig. 3 (a), (b), and (c), respectively, the proposed method achieves performance that is the most similar to that with full client participation. Moreover, it exhibits faster convergence speed and superior test accuracy compared to prior works. Notably, there is an approximate 20%percent2020\% improvement in the 1SPC scenario and an 8%percent88\% improvement in the 2SPC and Dir scenarios. Similar trends are also observed for the CIFAR-10 dataset.

V-B2 Time Overhead Analysis

We evaluate the time overhead of the proposed client selection strategy, and the results are presented in Table I. The time overhead analysis is conducted on the FMNIST dataset under the 1SPC scenario, with similar observations across other scenarios. In Table I, the first row focuses on the time solely for client selection within a communication round, while the second row denotes the overall time required for a complete communication round, including client selection, local updates, and global aggregation.

First, examining the time solely for client selection, our proposed method exhibits only a marginal increase (less than 0.4ms) compared to existing methods. This increment is acceptable in most real applications. In addition, the time required for client selection (about 0.5ms) is almost negligible compared to the total time required to complete a communication round (about 2000ms). This highlights that the majority of time is allocated to local updates within clients. Second, examining the time required to complete a round, our proposed strategy imposes only a modest additional computational time (about 400 ms) compared to existing approaches. This is primarily because evaluating the distance Disti,j​(t)subscriptDist𝑖𝑗𝑡\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t) in Eq. (5) is time-consuming, especially when the dimension of ∇fi​(𝒘t)∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) is high. The time overhead can be reduced by employing a more efficient method for calculating distances in high-dimensional gradient space. Nevertheless, the marginal increase in time for the proposed strategy is justified when considering its superior performance in client selection.

V-B3 Visualization of Client Selection Strategy

We provide visualizations of the selected clients to offer an interpretable analysis of our proposed strategy. As shown in Fig. 4, in the 1SPC scenario on the FMNIST dataset, baseline methods typically select two or more clients from the same cluster. In contrast, the proposed LongFed, as shown in 4 (e), selects one client from each cluster, which effectively approximates the data distribution of the full client set. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 4 (f), it chooses a diverse subset of clients in the multi-round selection, adhering to Principle II.

The results in the 2SPC scenario are illustrated in Fig. 5, where the clustering pattern is not evident. For baseline methods, the circles around selected clients often overlap and cover only a minority of clients. However, in our proposed method, as shown in Fig. 5 (e), these circles cover the majority of clients. This suggests that the selected clients provide a better approximation of the full client set compared to the baseline approaches. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 5 (f), the strategy selects a diverse subset of clients across multiple rounds, satisfying Principle II. Visualization results of other scenarios are provided in the supplementary file.

V-C Individual Fairness Analysis

We analyze the proposed individual fairness in terms of the trade-off factor V𝑉V, the similarity measure ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, and the probability difference measure δ𝛿\delta. The results are illustrated using the 2SPC scenario on the CIFAR-10 dataset, and similar trends are observed for other scenarios. The random selection strategy is chosen as the baseline because it selects clients randomly and without bias. The impact of these parameters is assessed through two metrics: test accuracy and the standard deviation of the selection probability pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} between clients with similar data distributions, denoted as σ​(t)𝜎𝑡\sigma(t). To calculate σ​(t)𝜎𝑡\sigma(t), we define ci​(t)subscript𝑐𝑖𝑡c_{i}(t) as the accumulated number of selections for client i𝑖i during previous t𝑡t communication rounds. That is, ci​(t)=∑k=1txi,ksubscript𝑐𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘c_{i}(t)=\sum_{k=1}^{t}x_{i,k}. For each client i𝑖i, we identify clients whose similarity with it is less than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, denoted as 𝕀i​(t)={j∈ℕ∣Disti,j​(t)<ϵ}subscript𝕀𝑖𝑡conditional-set𝑗ℕsubscriptDist𝑖𝑗𝑡italic-ϵ\mathbb{I}_{i}(t)=\{j\in\mathbb{N}\mid\text{Dist}_{i,j}(t)<\epsilon\}. We then compute the average selection count among clients in 𝕀i​(t)subscript𝕀𝑖𝑡\mathbb{I}_{i}(t) by

c¯i​(t)=1|𝕀i​(t)|​∑j∈𝕀i​(t)cj​(t),subscript¯𝑐𝑖𝑡1subscript𝕀𝑖𝑡subscript𝑗subscript𝕀𝑖𝑡subscript𝑐𝑗𝑡\displaystyle\overline{c}_{i}(t)=\frac{1}{|\mathbb{I}_{i}(t)|}\sum_{j\in\mathbb{I}_{i}(t)}c_{j}(t), (33)

and the standard deviation in their selection counts by

σ​(t)=1N​∑i=1N[ci​(t)−c¯i​(t)]2.𝜎𝑡1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑐𝑖𝑡subscript¯𝑐𝑖𝑡2\displaystyle\sigma(t)=\sqrt{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[c_{i}(t)-\overline{c}_{i}(t)\right]^{2}}. (34)

A smaller σ​(t)𝜎𝑡\sigma(t) indicates that the client selection strategy aligns more closely with the individual fairness constraint.

Trade-Off Factor V𝑉V. We vary the value of V𝑉V from 0.00.00.0, 0.40.40.4, 0.60.60.6, and 1.01.01.0, and present the results in Fig. 6. First, we observe that the proposed method with these four values converges faster than the random strategy and achieves better performance. Among them, V=0.6𝑉0.6V=0.6 yields the best test accuracy. This suggests that the individual fairness constraint improves the overall performance. Second, the random strategy achieves the lowest standard deviation σ​(t)𝜎𝑡\sigma(t). The proposed method exhibits significantly larger σ​(t)𝜎𝑡\sigma(t) when V=1.0𝑉1.0V=1.0. This is because when V=1.0𝑉1.0V=1.0, our proposed method prioritizes minimizing the estimation error in Eq. (2) and neglects the fairness constraint. Furthermore, the standard deviation σ​(t)𝜎𝑡\sigma(t) decreases significantly when V≤0.6𝑉0.6V\leq 0.6. It indicates that the constraint in Eq. (7) indeed enhances the system fairness.

Similarity Measure ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. We vary the value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon across 0.050.050.05, 0.10.10.1, 0.20.20.2, and 0.30.30.3, and observe the corresponding test accuracy and standard deviation, as presented in Fig. 7. First, the results on test accuracy indicate that the proposed method outperforms the random strategy consistently across these ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon values. On the other hand, a larger ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in the proposed method corresponds to a smaller standard deviation. Specifically, the results are comparable to the random selection strategy when ϵ>0.05italic-ϵ0.05\epsilon>0.05, and even surpass it when ϵ=0.3italic-ϵ0.3\epsilon=0.3. This is attributed to the fact that a larger ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon enforces more clients to follow the fairness constraint, thus the standard deviation obtained through the proposed strategy gets closer to the random selection strategy.

Probability Difference Measure δ𝛿\delta. We vary the value of δ𝛿\delta across 0.010.010.01, 0.10.10.1, 0.150.150.15, and 0.20.20.2, and observe the corresponding test accuracy and standard deviation, as presented in Fig. 8. The results indicate that the proposed method consistently performs better than the random selection strategy across these δ𝛿\delta values in terms of test accuracy. Moreover, a smaller δ𝛿\delta in the proposed method corresponds to a smaller standard deviation. This is because a smaller δ𝛿\delta narrows the range of probability difference between clients with similar distributions, resulting in a smaller standard deviation.

VI Conclusion

In our work, we introduce a novel long-term client selection approach for federated learning, aiming to emulate the optimization trajectory achieved by full client participation. We establish two guiding principles to steer the client selection process effectively. We formulate the client selection problem as a long-term optimization task, where the objective is to minimize the estimation error in gradient space between the selected subset of clients and the full client set. Besides, we impose the individual fairness constraint to ensure similar selection frequencies among clients with similar data distributions. Leveraging Lyapunov optimization techniques from control theory, we transform this problem and propose a greedy algorithm to find solutions efficiently. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed strategy closely approximates the performance achieved under full client participation, with significant improvements over previous methods in terms of both accuracy and fairness. Additionally, our method exhibits efficiency by incurring minimal time overhead, which is often negligible when compared to local training duration.

VII Additional Details of The Proposed Optimization Function

VII-A Proof of Theorem 1

Proof.

Following the analysis in [32], based on the mapping ξt:ℕ→𝕊t:superscript𝜉𝑡→ℕsuperscript𝕊𝑡\xi^{t}:\mathbb{N}\rightarrow\mathbb{S}^{t} that assigns each client i∈ℕ𝑖ℕi\in\mathbb{N} to a client j∈𝕊t𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}, we have

∑i∈ℕ∇fi​(𝒘t)subscript𝑖ℕ∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\displaystyle\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t}) =∑i∈ℕ[∇fi​(𝒘t)−∇fξt​(i)​(𝒘t)+∇fξt​(i)​(𝒘t)]absentsubscript𝑖ℕdelimited-[]∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝑓superscript𝜉𝑡𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝑓superscript𝜉𝑡𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\displaystyle\quad=\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\left[\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{\xi^{t}(i)}(\bm{w}^{t})+\nabla f_{\xi^{t}(i)}(\bm{w}^{t})\right] (35)
=∑i∈ℕ[∇fi​(𝒘t)−∇fξt​(i)​(𝒘t)]+∑j∈𝕊tθjt​∇fj​(𝒘t).absentsubscript𝑖ℕdelimited-[]∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝑓superscript𝜉𝑡𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝒘𝑡\displaystyle\quad=\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\left[\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{\xi^{t}(i)}(\bm{w}^{t})\right]+\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t}).

Subtracting and taking the norm of the both sides, we have

‖∑i∈ℕ∇fi​(𝒘t)−∑j∈𝕊tθjt​∇fj​(𝒘t)‖≤∑i∈ℕ‖∇fi​(𝒘t)−∇fξt​(i)​(𝒘t)‖.normsubscript𝑖ℕ∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑖ℕnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝑓superscript𝜉𝑡𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\displaystyle\big{\|}\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}\leq\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\big{\|}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{\xi^{t}(i)}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}. (36)

The upper bound is minimized when ξtsuperscript𝜉𝑡\xi^{t} assigns each client i∈ℕ𝑖ℕi\in\mathbb{N} to the client in the subset 𝕊tsuperscript𝕊𝑡\mathbb{S}^{t} that has the highest similarity in the gradient space. That is,

ξt​(i)∈argminj∈𝕊t​‖∇fi​(𝒘t)−∇fj​(𝒘t)‖,superscript𝜉𝑡𝑖subscriptargmin𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡norm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝒘𝑡\displaystyle\xi^{t}(i)\in\text{argmin}_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\big{\|}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}, (37)

Therefore, we have

minθjt⁡‖∑i∈ℕ∇fi​(𝒘t)−∑j∈𝕊tθjt​∇fj​(𝒘t)‖≤∑i∈ℕminj∈𝕊t⁡‖∇fi​(𝒘t)−∇fj​(𝒘t)‖,subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡normsubscript𝑖ℕ∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝑖ℕsubscript𝑗superscript𝕊𝑡norm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝒘𝑡\displaystyle\min_{\theta_{j}^{t}}\big{\|}\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\sum_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\theta_{j}^{t}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}\leq\sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\min_{j\in\mathbb{S}^{t}}\big{\|}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{w}^{t})-\nabla f_{j}(\bm{w}^{t})\big{\|}, (38)

which completes the proof. ∎

VII-B Proof of Theorem 2

Proof.

We first present the theoretical analysis for Zi​(t)subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡Z_{i}(t). Based on Eq. (13), we have

Zi​(t+1)≥Zi​(t)+xi,t−xi⁣⋆,t−δ,subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿\displaystyle Z_{i}(t+1)\geq Z_{i}(t)+x_{i,t}-x_{i\star,t}-\delta, (39)

which is equivalent to

xi,t−xi⁣⋆,t−δ≤Zi​(t+1)−Zi​(t).subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑍𝑖𝑡\displaystyle x_{i,t}-x_{i\star,t}-\delta\leq Z_{i}(t+1)-Z_{i}(t). (40)

Accumulating this inequality by t𝑡t for t∈[1,T]𝑡1𝑇t\in[1,T], we have

∑t=1T(xi,t−xi⁣⋆,t−δ)≤Zi​(T)−Zi​(0)=Zi​(T).superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿subscript𝑍𝑖𝑇subscript𝑍𝑖0subscript𝑍𝑖𝑇\displaystyle\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(x_{i,t}-x_{i\star,t}-\delta\right)\leq Z_{i}(T)-Z_{i}(0)=Z_{i}(T). (41)

Taking the expectation operation 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} on both sides, we have

1T​∑t=1T𝔼​(xi,t−xi⁣⋆,t)−δ≤𝔼​[Zi​(T)]T.1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑍𝑖𝑇𝑇\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}\left(x_{i,t}-x_{i\star,t}\right)-\delta\leq\frac{\mathbb{E}[Z_{i}(T)]}{T}. (42)

It is equivalent to

limT→+∞𝔼​[Zi​(T)]T=0⇒1T​∑t=1T𝔼​(xi,t−xi⋆,t)−δ≤0,∀i∈ℕ.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝑇𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑍𝑖𝑇𝑇0⇒1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝔼subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥superscript𝑖⋆𝑡𝛿0for-all𝑖ℕ\displaystyle\lim_{T\to+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{E}[Z_{i}(T)]}{T}=0\;\Rightarrow\;\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathbb{E}(x_{i,t}-x_{i^{\star},t})-\delta\leq 0,\;\forall\,i\in\mathbb{N}. (43)

The proof is similar for Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t), and is omitted here. ∎

Lemma 1.

Based on Eq. (13), we have

Proof.

VIII Additional Details of The Convergence Analysis

VIII-A Proof of Theorem 4

Proof.

Our theoretical analysis is based on the FedAvg [1] method, and it can also be extended to other federated optimization methods. To align with the approach in [42], we unify the epochs of local training in clients and communication rounds for parameter transmission between the server and clients into a single dimension, indexed by t=s​E+k𝑡𝑠𝐸𝑘t=sE+k. Here, s𝑠s denotes the index of the current communication round, E𝐸E is the number of local epochs in a communication round, and k∈[1,E−1]𝑘1𝐸1k\in[1,E-1]. If t𝑡t is divisible by E𝐸E (indicated as t∣Econditional𝑡𝐸t\mid E), it signifies the communication step where the server aggregates the model parameters from the selected clients. Otherwise, it represents a local training step for clients.

Based on 𝒗itsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑖𝑡\bm{v}_{i}^{t} and 𝒘itsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}^{t}, we define two virtual sequences 𝒗¯tsuperscript¯𝒗𝑡\bar{\bm{v}}^{t} and 𝒘¯tsuperscript¯𝒘𝑡\bar{\bm{w}}^{t},

with β>1/μ𝛽1𝜇\beta>{1}/{\mu} and γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 to achieve a diminishing learning rate, we complete the proof.

∎

IX Additional Details of Experiment

IX-A Experimental Settings

Following [18], for the FMNIST dataset, we employ a multilayer perceptron with two hidden layers as the global model, where the number of units in the two hidden layers is 64 and 30, respectively. Additionally, we set the number of local epochs to 3, the local batch size to 64, and the learning rate to 0.0050.0050.005. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, the architecture of the global model is a convolutional neural network (CNN) with three convolutional layers having 32, 64, and 64 kernels, respectively. All kernels are designed with the size 3×3333\times 3. Besides, the outputs of the convolutional layers are fed into an MLP layer with 64 units. We set the number of local epochs to 5, the local batch size to 128, and the learning rate to 0.05.

IX-B Visualization of Client Selection Strategy

The visualization results in Fig. 9 for the FMNIST dataset under the Dir scenario are similar to the 2SPC scenario. Specifically, in Fig. 9 (b)-(d), the circles around selected clients for baseline methods often overlap and cover only a minority of clients. Moreover, as depicted in Fig. 9 (e), the clients selected by our proposed method effectively cover the majority of remaining clients. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 9 (f), the strategy selects different clients in different rounds, adhering to the fairness constraint.

For further insights, we provide visualizations for the CIFAR-10 dataset in the 1SPC, 2SPC, and Dir scenarios in Fig. 10, Fig. 11, and Fig. 12, respectively. The conclusions drawn from the CIFAR-10 dataset align with those from the FMNIST dataset.
